preReqs: One of CHEM 203, CHEM 223, CHEM 233.
description: Introduction to proteins and enzymes, carbohydrate metabolism, and glucose homeostasis. The course emphasis is on human biochemistry and it is designed for students going into health science fields. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203 or BIOL 201.
title: Introductory Medical Biochemistry

sections.comments: This section of BIOC202 is only for students in the Biomedical Engineering program.
sections.building: P. A. Woodward Instructional Resources Centre

sections.comments: Wait list for BIOC202.002 (term 2)

preReqs: BIOL 200 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 223.
description: Amino acids and proteins. Enzymes and enzymology. Human metabolic pathways. Structure, function and metabolism of carbohydrates including glycogen storage and gluconeogenesis. Restricted to students in Biochemistry specializations. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203 or BIOL 201.
title: Fundamentals of Biochemistry

sections.building: P. A. Woodward Instructional Resources Centre
P. A. Woodward Instructional Resources Centre

preReqs: One of BIOC 300, BIOC 302, BIOC 303.
description: Techniques by which the chemical and physical properties of fundamental components of the cell are studied.
title: Biochemistry Laboratory

sections.comments: Entry to this course is normally restricted to third year students in Biochemistry major and honours programs, who have completed appropriate 1st and 2nd year program requirements, and to Physiology, Pharmacology and Honours Biophysics students who have received approval for their programs.  The academic records of all students who register into the course will be checked and those not having an appropriate academic background for their designated specialization will be de-registered. Additionally, registration in co-requisite courses (Bioc 302 or Bioc 303) will be checked and any students not registered in the appropriate course may be removed from Bioc 301.No preference is given to 4th year students and, accordingly, direct registration is restricted to students with 3rd year standing in the Faculty of Science.  Eligible 4th year students needing to take the course should register into the wait-list section and contact the Biochemistry adviser (jaread@mail.ubc.ca) to request entry to the course.  Approved 4th year students will be registered by the department when their academic standing matches that of the incoming 3rd year class.
Students who do not attend check-in may be de-registered from the course. Contact the instructor at 604-822-7582 (Email: jaread@mail.ubc.ca) if you are unable to attend.
Students who do not attend check-in may be de-registered from the course. Contact the instructor at 604-822-7582 (Email: jaread@interchange.ubc.ca) if you are unable to attend.
Students who do not attend check-in may be de-registered from the course. Contact the instructor at 604-822-7582 (Email: jaread@interchange.ubc.ca) if you are unable to attend.
Students who do not attend check-in may be de-registered from the course.  Contact the instructor at 604-822-7582 (Email: jaread@interchange.ubc.ca) if you are unable to attend.

Wait list for lab and lecture; students wanting to be considered for admission to the course should register into the wait list and contact the Biochemistry adviser (jaread@interchange.ubc.ca) to outline their reasons for wanting to take BIOC301.-  Wait listing does not guarantee placement in the course - please check the SSC periodically to determine if you have been moved into the course, and ensure that your Email address on the UBC system is up-to-date to receive Email announcements about the status of the wait list. Students with weak or deficient academic records, who have no probability of being placed in the course, will be de-registered from the wait list.

preReqs: One of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 223, CHEM 233.
description: Metabolic reactions of lipids, steroids, amino acids and nucleotides; the biochemistry of replication, transcription and translation. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 302 or BIOC 303.
title: General Biochemistry

preReqs: One of BIOC 203, BIOC 202, BIOL 201 and either (a) CHEM 213 or (b) all of CHEM 205, CHEM 233.
description: Structure, function and metabolism of lipids, steroids, amino acids and nucleotides; the biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, translation and gene regulation. For students in Biochemistry and Honours programs in other life sciences.  Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 302 or BIOC 303.
title: Molecular Biochemistry

preReqs: CHEM 213.
description: Exploration of the breadth and importance of biochemical research to present day challenges in medicine and biotechnology. Detailed experimental research case studies of novel biochemical methods used to address pressing and ongoing biochemical issues.
title: Contemporary Biochemical Research

sections.comments: Web-oriented course.

preReqs: (Completion of academic third year in Biochemistry major or honours program is required.)
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic laboratory for three or four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.
title: Internship Work Placement I

description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

preReqs: One of BIOC 302, BIOC 303, BIOT 380. (A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.)
description: Structural components of proteins, classification by primary, secondary and tertiary structure, protein chemistry and purification, peptide and protein synthesis by chemical means and three-dimensional structure determination using X-ray diffraction and NMR.
title: Proteins: Structure and Function

sections.comments: Tutorial sessions are held in LSC 1410.
sections.building: P. A. Woodward Instructional Resources Centre

sections.comments: Held in LSI building room 1410
Held in LSI building room 1410

preReqs: BIOC 402. (A minimum standing of 65% is recommended.)
description: Kinetic analysis, catalytic mechanisms, transition state stabilization and regulation of activity, strategies for active site characterization and case studies of well-documented enzyme systems. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 403, CHEM 413 or CHEM 569.
title: Enzymology

sections.building: P. A. Woodward Instructional Resources Centre

description: Theory and application of classical and emerging technologies in biochemical research.  Emphasis on using primary literature and oral presentation skills.  Restricted to Honours students in Biochemistry or others with permission of the instructor.
title: Biochemical Methods

preReqs: Either (a) all of BIOC 303, BIOL 335 or (b) BIOT 380. (A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.)
description: Chemical, physical and biological properties of nucleic acids and their role in replication, transcription, translation and regulation of expression of genetic material. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 410 or BIOC 510.
title: Nucleic Acids-Structure and Function

sections.comments: Tutorial sessions are held in LSI room 1510
BIOC410 tutorial.  Held in LSI building, room 1510.

preReqs: One of BIOC 404, FSCT 480.
description: Multi-week experiments in areas of contemporary biochemistry research using classical and modern techniques.  Emphasis on experimental design, technique, critical analysis of data, and scientific communication skills.  Restricted to Honours students in Biochemistry and others with permission of the instructor.
title: Advanced Biochemical Techniques

sections.comments: This section is for students in the honours forensics specialization.
This section is for biochemistry students in the honours specializations.

preReqs: All of BIOC 301, BIOC 410.
description: Multi-week experiments involving contemporary nucleic acid research, cloning and recombinant protein engineering. Emphasis is on experimental design, critical analysis of data and scientific communication skills.  Restricted to Major students in Biochemistry.
title: Recombinant DNA Techniques

sections.comments: Wait List for BIOC421

preReqs: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.
description: Developing areas of molecular biology, focusing on experimental design and data analysis. Signal transduction, the use of model eukaryotes, and the regulation of gene expression.
title: Concepts in Molecular Biology

sections.comments: The lecture is held in LSC 1510.

description: Biochemistry of membranes and membrane proteins, membrane fusion, electrical signaling, and the involvement of membrane proteins in disease and drug development.

description: Biochemical basis of select global challenges. Critical evaluation of primary literature to form evidence-based opinions and communicating biochemistry as it relates to several controversial societal issues.

preReqs: ar class where Biochemistry graduate students present their thesis research. Students will receive a grade after presenting two seminars over a three term period. Students can't register for this course online but the graduate office will automatically registers any participants.
